bioghist.p: John Roach (1813-1887) was a noted manufacturer and iron ship builder. He was born at Mitchellstown, County Cork, Ireland, and came to America at the age of 16. He purchased the Reaney, Son & Archbold shipyard in Chester, Pennsylvania, and in 1871 renamed it John Roach and Sons. The shipyard had a distinguished career building fine ships before it closed in 1922. It was revived for the war effort in 1917 but was acquired by Averell Harriman's American Ship & Commerce Corporation in 1919 and renamed Merchant Shipbuilding. Roach and his wife Emeline had several children, including John B. Roach. John B. Roach (1839-1908) was the head of the Delaware River Iron Shipbuilding & Engine Works of Chester, and vice president of the Morgan Iron Works of New York City.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of papers of John Roach, John B. Roach, and the Roach family. Records related to Roach and Sons shipyard include: souvenir books, 1895; lists of ships and boilers built; patents, receipts, work reports, bids, and a list of sponsors (1873-1891); a photocopy of a register of ships built by Roach between 1872 and 1907, in two volumes; brochures of ships built by Roach; and a printed register of contracts for Reaney, Son and Archbold, Roach and Sons, and Merchant Shipbuilding Corp, 1859-1921. John Roach papers include: draft notice; deeds, leases, and mortgages; papers related to Roach's estate; several speeches and manuscript; correspondence sent to him during his illness; printed memorials and obituaries; and correspondence sent to him during his dispute with the Navy. Other materials related to the "Navy controversy" include newspaper clippings and articles, congressional bills, correspondence, statements, and a galley proof of "Secretary Whitney and the Dolphin," by John Roach, 1886. Family papers include: correspondence of Mrs. G. R. Forbes related to Roach family genealogy; photographs from County Cork, Ireland; a family genealogy; photographs of Roach, Roach family members, and a small number of photos of ships; and a 1914 photo album of the Roach family in Cape Cod. The collection also contains newspaper clippings and magazine articles on Roach's Shipyard, launchings and new contracts, the Dolphin controversy, and on John Roach and members of the Roach family. There are also a number of pamphlets on tariff laws (undated).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
